reviewText:
TL;DR, I highly, highly recommend playing this game, but I do not recommend buying it. This is one of the coolest concepts I have ever seen destroyed by an unusable DRM scheme.

From Dust is a work of art. Watching the form of the earth change and mould as the player manipulates it brings back memories of Black and White, but with a sense of visual awe that comes from being a much more recent game. It is something that I feel any gamer owes it to themselves to experience at least once. Sadly, I can't recommend buying the game, as I have an ethical objection to UPlay. The alternative, a Chrome app that is free in the Chrome Store, is okay, but ultimately Ubisoft's disingenuity has ruined, or at least limited access to, what I consider to be an actual art piece.

Fun fact: Ubisoft actually patched the game to remove UPlay. I had been hoping that would happen and bought it shortly after. Only a few months later, I had been happily enjoying my new game when I launched one day to find UPlay had been patched back in.

Ubisoft, I know you're not listening, but stop punishing your customers for buying your products. You did the right thing once before and removed the DRM from this game. Now that the DRM is back on, I would not be surprised to find the number of seeders for this game on torrent sites has spiked. No one wants a content management system inside another content management system, especially if they only have one or two games in the nested" one."

reviewText:
First of all this game will require Uplay to play and you will have to lock your serial to that one account so don't forget the information. While annoying, this is doable and not the only game like it. Wish I had read more of the steam reviews before buying. I would not recommend this game and if you already bought it, my sympathies, but it is not the next Black and White. Buy at own risk, I cannot stress this enough.

Controls and Mechanics: Saw a lot of complaints about this. Some buttons are counter intuitive or not 'the norm' but you can grow accustomed to them fairly quickly there's only two really weird ones. UI is spare so you aren't overwhelmed with options. Movement of the cursor corresponds with the movement of your avatar and 90% of the time this is fine and you get used to it fast. The other 10% of the time it will go too far too fast or something at just the wrong time and Bad Things will happen because of it (this has caused me to restart at least one map). Similarly 1-2-3-4 isn't hard to remember, but when the powers attributed to them shift around you have to constantly check the menu to make sure you're using the right power.

The AI of the people is actually fairly decent - when it works. When it doesn't you get dozens of annoying little voices screaming at you from the top of a hastily erected pillar as rivers of lava flow around them, voices which you cannot stop until either that lava does, or one of your powers comes up, etc. Furthermore idiotic people have cost me wins before, causing me to have to restart some maps several times or making simple tasks very hard.

Camera: Similar to dungeon crawlers, up above and slightly behind the avatar with the option to zoom in a little or to zoom in completely (and not be able to do anything) on just one of your humans. Like the controls 90% of the time this is fine, but when it goes wrong it can be very frustrating giving the fast liquids you are working with.

Now to the reason I am writing this review: some spoilers ahead (I try not to name names).




Surprisingly interesting premise and I genuinely wanted to see my people through and to find out more about what had happened before me. The cut scene between maps gets annoying overtime since its pretty long and just the same footage over and over again but that's not game breaking. What is game breaking is the end. The last level. First of all the game froze just as I was about to complete it so I had to go back and do it all over again (first time this had happened). I hesitate to detail what exactly happens but suffice to say that I was extraordinarily displeased, felt that absolutely NONE of the plot points were tied up (they didn't even try to softball something in or if they did it was too subtle for my shock and disappointment to see it), we weren't given any revelations or massive info dumps, its one giant screw you to the idiot stupid enough to waste their time on this game. Before the end I was willing to give this game a pass and say there were some levels worth redoing, some content worth getting every little bit from, but afterwards I uninstalled the game without second thoughts.

reviewText:
Really awesome until the last few levels. Before the later stages, it was relaxing, like playing in a sandbox, yet reasonably challenging without being frustrating or punishing.

Unfortunately, as I got to the later stages, difficulty arose due to a certain totem being placed in a very tricky, high and near-lava location. You have to rely on the individual pathing of the AI, but there's not much indication if they'll be able to get up slopes (when there's multiple potential routes to a location) so trying to get them to this totem without having them try to cross lava is an exercise in frustration. The AI pathing tends to be annoying to deal with as the stages get harder. Also, depending on how you may have tried to build walls in stages with lava, you may find yourself having spent a lot of time on a stage but in a sitation where you'll have to try to destroy some walls to let your villagers get to a totem. Doing this is tedious because you need to use explosive plants (if you made rock walls). I don't understand the point in letting players manipulate something in such a tedious way instead of providing a less time-consuming method.

Overall, dealing with the lava is quite frustrating, especially with how it can completely wipe out villages if so much as a particle touches some of your greenery. I understand having a challenge makes things more fun, but the way this challenge is presented is more frustrating than entertaining, because a small mistake can reset your entire stage progress.

Slight variation on the level design and the lava mechanics would've probably made the game fun, but as it is I can't recommend it because of the unpleasantness of the later levels. Challenge should not come from dealing with the stupid AI, and mistakes shouldn't make you feel like you've just wasted a bunch of time, because that's no fun. Towards the end it just became not pleasant to play anymore. It's a shame because the sandbox mechanics are very entertaining to interact with - it's almost like they weren't sure whether they wanted to frustrate players with hard challenges or provide a relaxing, slow-paced sandbox game.

reviewText:
I'd recommend this game but with a couple of major reservations.

First off the good.

I think the core mechanics are neat and well executed. Moving terrain around and using it to affect the lives of the indigenous population is great fun. The fun for me at least partially stems from my sense of nostalgia of playing in the backyard and digging out villages for my populations of action figures to live in. Also, I have a weak spot for games in which physics manipulation is the basis of the mechanics.

Now for the bad

First off screw uPlay. This game somehow got deleted from my uPlay account so now I can only play it in offline mode. However I can't inherently judge the game for that failure, just Ubisoft's publishing policies. Buyer beware, I guess.

Second, it feels like a console port. There's minimal graphics options. The controls are awkward and become a hindrance on the later, faster paced levels. The menus are unpolished and make it a pain to navigate between level selection and other important features.

In conclusion I liked this game but there are some major issues with it's packaging. If From Dust was remade or they made a sequel that controlled better, operated better on the PC environment, and didn’t include mandatory uPlay integration, then I would definitely be able to recommend it.

reviewText:
From Dust is the last game from Eric Chahi (known for Another World and Heart of Darkenss). COntrary to his most famous creations which were side scrolling adventures, From Dust is a God-game.

To make this review short, I thoroughly enjoyed it and I spent about 18 hours with the main missions, not touching the challanges, so it has plenty of content to keep you satisfied. Plus the game looks amazing. The only gameplay-related minus is the lack of a sandbox mode, but that's alleviated by the fact that the last mission is exactly that: a sandbox mode. Though I think it should have been a separate mode, not locked at the end of the campaign.

Now, to speak a bit about its technical problems. I will start by saying that I had absolutely no problem with any of the problems most people bring up when talking about From Dust, and I wholeheartedly recommend it.
Its most common problems are:
- bad mouse and keyboard controls. I was not affected as I played with a gamepad. If you own a gamepad (and most PC users do nowadays), do yourself a favor and play this game with it. It wills ave you a lot of frustration and it will help you enjoy the game.
- locked framerate. Yes, the game is locked at 30fps and there are no excuses but: it hasn't bothered me at all since this is an incredibly slow paced game. In this case 30fps is completely acceptable and doesn't realy break the game or the immersion in any way.
- uPlay. Everyone and their mother are complaining about uPlay. It didn't bother me at all, and to be honest I don't see how anyone that isn't a kid would be bothered by it. It is just another UI layer that didn't bother me at all. It just loads with the game and remains in the background while I play. Just like steam. To be bothered by one but not by the other is completely immature in my opinion.
- Always online DRM. By the time I played this game, Ubisoft removed always online DRM so right now this is a non-issue.

If you like god-games, do yourslef a favor and play From Dust. It's not really as good as the pold Populous games (nostalgia may be a factor in my case), but it is still pretty good and offers a lot of content. The game is also pretty cheap nowadays (you can get it in a sale for 5 dollars or euros).

I mean if they had even been better programmed to be more interactive just with one another and their environments, it would have been sufficient for me to feel like an actual all-powerful god watching over my people.  Fact is, they just threw up cookie-cutter village spheres and then sat around waiting for me to do something.  I would have greatly enjoyed watching them fish and farm and hunt or just about anything which made them feel alive to the gamer.  I really think that, with the bare bones nature of your godly influence in the world of From Dust, this game needed more content and variety within its little living world.

So, if the game is on sale and you enjoy god-like games, physics/cause-effect, give it a go. I personally felt like “is that it?” at the end. So expect that if you like these sort of games.

But still, the concept is good and this is the only game out there where you can manipulate the world like this, and it’s fun. So + for me.

I love this game. It has fantastic atmosphere and it just looks and feels great. It is a story that is not directly put in words or told to you. It is an experience. A journey.

You act as a god of a tribe assisting them in their search for their ancestors. The gameplay is really interesting and is based entirely on modifying the terrain in various ways and it works really well. The gameplay revolves around grabbing materials and objects and moving them elsewhere. It sounds boring when described but it very satisfying in-game.

There are also tsunamis that cover the entire map, and spontaneous volcanoes to mess up your finely tuned plans. Sometimes the game gets seriously difficult. I remember trying to beat a few levels for several hours.

The graphics are stunning and it has good replayability. I've played the game through twice and it's really easy to pick up waste a few hours every once in a while. After you beat the game you unlock a sandbox mode where you can create your own small world. (So much fun!)

It seems that Steam did not record all those hours (~40) I've played this game.

A god game about moving dirt around. It's actually more fun than it sounds. You have to fiddle with the elements to make tiny people run around and build villages that either flood or burn down. Sometimes both at the same time. It's good for a while, but just becomes punishing difficult towards the end game.

God Games have always been one which you've have the overall power the wield the world at your fingertips, with each God Game type having their own different style to give, showing the emphasis of what type of god you are in that specific universe. Sometimes the wielding of nature (which is most common in god games) is used to a much greater advantage, one of which provides the player to have much more strategy that simply clicking on the environment. From Dust perfectly does this.

From Dust developed by Ubisoft is a game where you play as a deity which has the power to shift the lands underneath the native people's feet for their own means of survival. From Dust's story synopsis is about a group of native in which their land is torn by the natural causes, until they summon their god (the player) to help them strive to a new land in which they may find a peaceful location to settle on with any nature causes harming their colony.

The Story is told through a more native style tale which help give a more tribal and authentic feel to the games' art style, with such a story it can be consider to have contain a hidden message or parable. (Though I'll overlook that)

The gameplay is pretty much like other god games. You have to move around the natural element of the world to help suit the needs of the native people, to get from point A to B, which 'B' is a tunnel to the next level. The native people set up camp near a tribal totem pole in which it gives you various additional power to prevent natural disasters or pave way to an exit. This is the games' strongest point: the powers that the player has. The game makes it clear that you can grab and bend the natural element to your will. Ubisoft was clever with this technique as each level gives a limited amount of supply of a certain element. This is to make you strategise the current situation and makes you focus on rationing certain elements. Sometimes they give too much of an element and its up to the player to prevent that specific element destroy the tribes people. Sometimes this can done through kites which give special powers prevent certain elements from destroying the tribe.

The art style of the game is somewhat unique, in that it uses more tribal colours and texture which exist in more tropical environments, like Hawaii and Togo. The graphics are technically well designed with very little glitches or flaws that exist within the game.

The flaws that exist within the game are the sometimes unfairness of a certain level, elements attacking the tribe too quickly and giving a game over. Another is the AI which has a lack of pathfinding when going to a location which is perfect valid with no obstacles in the way. Last but not least is the somewhat lack of a sandbox mode or more time to use your creative skill in building nature constructs. Personally I had a great time using some elements to create damns and bridges, changing the flows of certain elements is what is highly enriching besides the strategy element of the game.

Overall From Dust is a great game which I highly recommend to anyone who loves God Games and want a bit more strategy as well.

God Games have always been one which you've have the overall power the wield the world at your fingertips, with each God Game type having their own different style to give, showing the emphasis of what type of god you are in that specific universe. Sometimes the wielding of nature (which is most common in god games) is used to a much greater advantage, one of which provides the player to have much more strategy that simply clicking on the environment. From Dust perfectly does this.

From Dust developed by Ubisoft is a game where you play as a deity which has the power to shift the lands underneath the native people's feet for their own means of survival. From Dust's story synopsis is about a group of native in which their land is torn by the natural causes, until they summon their god (the player) to help them strive to a new land in which they may find a peaceful location to settle on with any nature causes harming their colony.

The Story is told through a more native style tale which help give a more tribal and authentic feel to the games' art style, with such a story it can be consider to have contain a hidden message or parable. (Though I'll overlook that)

The gameplay is pretty much like other god games. You have to move around the natural element of the world to help suit the needs of the native people, to get from point A to B, which 'B' is a tunnel to the next level. The native people set up camp near a tribal totem pole in which it gives you various additional power to prevent natural disasters or pave way to an exit. This is the games' strongest point: the powers that the player has. The game makes it clear that you can grab and bend the natural element to your will. Ubisoft was clever with this technique as each level gives a limited amount of supply of a certain element. This is to make you strategise the current situation and makes you focus on rationing certain elements. Sometimes they give too much of an element and its up to the player to prevent that specific element destroy the tribes people. Sometimes this can done through kites which give special powers prevent certain elements from destroying the tribe.

The art style of the game is somewhat unique, in that it uses more tribal colours and texture which exist in more tropical environments, like Hawaii and Togo. The graphics are technically well designed with very little glitches or flaws that exist within the game.

The flaws that exist within the game are the sometimes unfairness of a certain level, elements attacking the tribe too quickly and giving a game over. Another is the AI which has a lack of pathfinding when going to a location which is perfect valid with no obstacles in the way. Last but not least is the somewhat lack of a sandbox mode or more time to use your creative skill in building nature constructs. Personally I had a great time using some elements to create damns and bridges, changing the flows of certain elements is what is highly enriching besides the strategy element of the game.

Overall From Dust is a great game which I highly recommend to anyone who loves God Games and want a bit more strategy as well.

From Dust is an entertaining game that stands out from similar civilization-type games in that you have to craft the land to assist and protect your native people as they go from increasingly inhospitable locations in an effort to find their Ancients who created their world. The story is basic (and not the focus of the game) and there are no real characters besides your virtually identical-looking natives and the only narrative is that which you hear at the begining of each stage. However the voice-over does stand out as it is spoken in a Bahasa Indonesian language that is neat to listen to and don't worry, there are subtitles in English.
The real fun comes from the gameplay where you gather up sand, lava, water and more in an effort to keep your people alive and help them to build and maintain their villages in ridiculously dangerous environments such as within the crater of an active volcano, hot damn! These scenarios can defintely be challenging as you will be forced to stop and think in order to plan the best course of terrain alteration or disaster will befall your villagers and you'll be forced to re-examine your strategy or even re-start the stage.
I also have to point out the level of realism attached to the various elements in that lava flows like you'd expect, water from tsunamis flows down from elevated portions of the land to pool in recesses, etc. Thanks to this you'll really feel like you're crafting a believable world and perhaps even learn to appreciate how difficult it must be for certain people (both past and present) to struggle against the elements.

Let me start by saying: From Dust is not a god-game and shouldn't be considered as such. It is not Populous (to which it has been compared to in various reviews) or Black & White or even Dungeon Keeper. And this is why people hate From Dust, they compare it to the wrong genre. Although you can't slap your people on the face, drown them intentionally or crush their homes and dreams (well, you can, but then it's game over) From Dust does have similarities to these titles. It has puny little humans and an omnipotent player that controls the surroundings and as such, indirectly also these puny little people. And it is beautiful and it has a physics engine unlike any other game. But in my view, From Dust is most reminicent of Lemmings: guide your people (the puny little humans) to safety via manipulation of the world around them. Raise the earth to create a bridge over water or drain a pond. And it is actually pretty cool. A bit repetitive in the long run perhaps, but a nice niche game.

Basic Gameplay: Once you make it safe, they will create this little outpost that generally gives you some kind of element manipulation buff such as evaporating all the water on the map. The outposts dont change at all. They only have to be protected from the elements. Your objective on every mission is to inhabit every outpost to proceed. Each mission has some sort of unique obstacle that sometimes requires thought to beat. Inbetween these missions you are  rewatching the same cinematic over and over. Thinking about it, it feels like an antfarm sim because you move elements around while you watch the ants do their own thing. Missions are easy. It is a good idea, 'meh' execution. Price should be somewhere around $10, $15 is steep. Pick it up on sale. One of those games that I dont regret playing, but should've passed on.

Now that I can safely say this is still working (uPlay is totally awful), I'm happy to report that this game is still as creative, beautiful and unique as it was in 2011. I've never played anything like it before or since. In fact, playing from dust when it first came out got me pretty interested in other simulation games like this, but none of them ever compared to what From Dust does.

The way you manipulate water in this game is really what does it for me. The way water flows, builds up, carries dirt, interacts with lava, surges in tides, gushes from holes in mountains, it's just all so well done and fascinating. I just spent an hour on the first level, watching water from two river sources carve out an enormous landmass from nothing.

This game is amazing, and it deserved far better than the treatment Ubisoft gave it. Bogging it down with uPlay basically condemned the game to a fate it didn't deserve.

But it really is an amazing game. I've never seen it on sale, but for $15 you're buying a pretty unique experience.
